artist: Kikugawa Eizan Published by Izumiya Ichibei
marks:
[我がいほハ都乃辰巳鹿ぞすむ世を宇治山と人ハいふなり]
{Waga iho wa/miyako n [菊川英山筆] {Kikugawa Eizan hitsu}
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
text:
A courtesan is juxtaposed to Kisen, a mid-ninth century Buddhist monk and poet of whom we only know that he lived near Mount Uji. The inscribed poem by him is cited in the "Collection of Japanese Poems of Ancient and Modern Times (<I>Kokin wakashu_<I>)" from around 905:

My hut is to the capital's southeast and thus I live. But people call it "Uji, hill of one weary of the world," I hear.
title: Monk Kisen
